sentences.sentence: I took a ship headed for( 驶向 ) the coast of Africa.
It was my luck to meet with pretty good company in London, which does not always happen to such young fellows as I then was.
I first met the captain of a ship which had visited the coast of Africa.
Having had very good success there, he was planning to go again.
Hearing me say I wanted to see the world, he told me that if I would take the voyage with him, I could do it as his companion.
I accepted the offer, entered into a close friendship with this captain, and I went on the voyage with him.
I carried a small supply of( 少量的 ) goods with me, the value of which I increased very considerably( 相当大地 ).
This was the only voyage which I may say was successful in all my adventures.
I owed( 将...归功于 ) my success to the honesty of my friend, the captain.
Under his instruction also I got a sufficient( 充足的 ) knowledge of the mathematics and the rules of sailing, and learned some other things that were necessary to understand as a sailor.
In a word, this voyage made me both a sailor and a merchant( 商人 ).
I traded the goods I had brought for five pounds nine ounces( 盎司 ) of gold dust, which earned me in London almost three hundred pounds.
This filled me with those ambitious( 野心勃勃的 ) thoughts which have since led to( 导致 ) my ruin.
I was now set up to be a trader. My friend the captain, to my great misfortune, died soon after( 不久之后 ).
I left 200 pounds of my newly gained wealth with my friend’s widow( 遗孀 ).
Carrying the remaining 100 pounds along with me, I set out( 启程 ) in the same ship as the one in which I took the previous voyage, now under a new captain.
This was the unhappiest voyage that ever anyone made, and I fell into terrible misfortunes.
The first misfortune occurred as our ship was heading towards the Canary Islands.
We were surprised in the gray of the morning by a Turkish( 土耳其的 ) pirate( 海盗 ) ship, which chased( 追赶 ) us with sails spread wide.
We also spread as much sail as we could, but finding the pirate( 海盗 ) gained upon( 逼近 ) us, we prepared to fight.
Our ship had twelve guns, and the pirates( 海盗 ) had eighteen.
About three in the afternoon they came up alongside( 与…并排 ) us, and we brought eight of our guns to face that side, and fired an attack upon their ship.
This made them turn away from us, but not before returning fire, both from their large guns and from the smaller weapons( 武器 ) in the hands of the nearly two hundred men on board their ship.
However, we had not a man injured, all our men keeping close together.
They prepared to attack us again, and we prepared to defend ourselves.
Sixty men entered our ship, and immediately began cutting the sails and ropes.
We attacked them with small guns, swords, and other such weapons( 武器 ), and got rid of( 摆脱 ) them twice.
However, our ship was disabled( 残损的 ), and three of our men killed.
We were forced to surrender( 投降 ). We were all carried as prisoners into Sallee, a port belonging to( 属于 ) the Moors( 摩尔人 ).
The way I was treated there was not so terrible as at first I had expected.
The rest of the sailors were taken to the ruler of the country to be his slaves, but I was kept by the captain of the pirates( 海盗 ) as his personal slave.

He had me taken to his house, and I hoped that he would take me with him when he went to sea again, believing that we might then be taken by a Spanish or Portuguese( 葡萄牙的 ) ship, and that then I should be set free( 释放 ).
But this hope of mine was soon taken away, for when he went to sea, he left me on shore to look after his little garden.
Here I thought of nothing but( 只有 ) escape, but found no way to manage it.
After about two years, something strange happened, which put the old thought again in my head of trying to escape.
My master was, for lack of money, staying at home longer than usual.
Once or twice a week, sometimes more often if the weather was good, he would take a boat and go out fishing.
We often went out fishing in this boat, and as I was very good at catching fish for him, he never went without me.
It happened one day that he had planned to go out in this boat with some important men.
Therefore, he had sent on board the boat a larger store of supplies than usual, and had ordered me to get three guns ready with gunpowder( 火药 ) and bullets( 子弹 ).
I got everything ready for his guests, and waited the next morning with the boat washed clean, when to my surprise my master came on board alone.
He told me his guests had some other business to attend( 处理 ) to, and ordered me to take a Moor( 摩尔人 ) and a boy to go out to catch some fish.
This moment my previous ideas of freedom returned into my thoughts, for now I found I was likely to( 很可能 ) have a boat at my command( 任由某人支配 ).
My master being gone, I prepared the boat, not for fishing business, but for a voyage.
I did not know where I should go. I just wanted to leave that place.
My first trick was to make an excuse to speak to the Moor( 摩尔人 ), to get something to eat on board, for I told him we must not dare to eat our master’s bread.
He said that was true, so he brought a large basket of biscuits, and three jars of fresh water( 淡水 ).
I carried also a great bag of wax( 蜡 ) into the boat, and a big ball of string( 细绳 ), an axe( 斧头 ), a saw( 锯子 ), and a hammer.
Thus supplied with everything necessary, we sailed out of the port to fish.
We were not more than a mile out of the port before we took down our sail and started to fish.
The wind blew from the North-East, which went against my plan.
Had it blown from the South, I would have been sure to have reached the coast of Spain.
But my plan was to be gone from that horrible( 可怕的 ) place, and leave the rest to destiny( 命运 ).
We had fished some time and caught nothing, for when I had fish on my hook I would not pull them up, so that the Moor( 摩尔人 ) would not see them.
I said to him, “This will not do—our master will not be happy with us if we do not bring back any fish—we must move farther out.”
He agreed, thinking no harm, and I ran the boat out farther.
Leaving the boy to steer( 掌舵 ) the boat, I stepped forward to where the Moor( 摩尔人 ) was.
I took him by surprise( 出其不意地袭击某人 ) with my arm under his waist, and threw him into the sea.
He rose immediately, for he swam like a fish, and called to me. He swam so strongly after the boat that he would have reached me very quickly.
I picked up one of the guns and pointed it at him.
I told him I had done him no harm, and if he would be quiet I would do him none.
“You swim well enough to reach the shore,” said I, “but if you come near the boat, I’ll shoot you through the head, for I must have my freedom.”
So he turned around, and swam for the shore. I do not doubt that he reached it easily, for he was an excellent swimmer.
When he was gone, I turned to the boy, whom they called Xury, and said to him: “Xury, if you will be faithful to me, I’ll make you a great man.
But if you will not swear( 发誓 ) to be true to me, I must throw you into the sea, too.”
The boy smiled sweetly, and spoke so innocently, that I could not distrust( 不信任 ) him. He swore( 发誓 ) to be faithful to me, and go all over the world with me.
